posts.name: Al's Italian Beef
posts.note: Al's Italian Beef is a Chicago-based chain known for overstuffed Italian beef sandwiches and hot dogs in a bare-bones space. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Athenian Room
posts.note: Athenian Room is a casual restaurant cooking Greek specialties like gyros and juice-soaked fries since the 1970s. Tina Fey recommended the Kalamata chicken dinner which is a half chicken over steak fries with lemon herb sauce that soaks in with the chicken fat to the fries.
posts.rcmmnd: Tina Fey on David Letterman show “My Next Guest Needs No Introduction”

posts.name: Bang Bang Pie and Biscuits
posts.note: Bang Bang Pie and Biscuits is a rustic bakery with a rotating menu of homemade sweet & savory pies & biscuits for eat-in or takeout. Phil from the show Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) recommends the candied bacon and the BLT Biscuit, or the sorghum butter, and for dessert, the peach pie with corneal crumble or the malted milk chocolate with whip cream or the pistachio and blueberry compote or peanut butter custard with raspberry preserves and toasted peanuts. From their website, 'Bang Bang Pie and Biscuits continues Mid-Western cooking traditions, eager to serve up our unique take on hospitality, decadence and cafe life.'

posts.name: Big Delicious Planet - Catering, Canteen, and Urban Farm
posts.note: Big Delicious Planet - Catering, Canteen, and Urban Farm is an inviting cafe connected to a catering operation offering coffee, pastries, and eco-focused meals. They have their own urban farm nearby. Its owner is Heidi Moorman Coudal. Yes, it's that Coudal.

posts.name: Billy Goat Tavern
posts.note: The Billy Goat Tavern is a Chicago legend since 1934 associated with the Cubs curse and Saturday Night Live. 'Cheezeborger, cheezeborger' and more in an underground haunt made famous by a recurring SNL skit. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Bob Chinn's Crab House
posts.note: Bob Chinn's has been an institution since 1982 in Wheeling IL. For over 35 years they have served some of the Freshest Seafood from around the globe- Alaska, Hawaii, New Zealand - to name a few. Specializing in seafood, they're also known for our wet-aged prime steaks that are comparable to some of the best steakhouses. Starting off as a restaurant that only seated 200, expanded to over 700 seats in five years. Come inside and judge for yourself on the quality and freshness of the finest food you will ever taste, served by their friendly and enthusiastic staff.

posts.name: Chicago French Market
posts.note: Chicago French Market is a European-inspired indoor food market for grab-and-go meals, fresh produce, and specialty kiosks.

posts.name: Cindy's Rooftop
posts.note: Cindy's Rooftop is a hip, stylish rooftop bar/eatery at the Chicago Athletic Association Hotel with choice seasonal fare. Phil from the Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) show recommends going there for drinks. From their website, 'The Jewel in the Crown Of The Chicago Athletic Association Hotel, Cindy's Rooftop Restaurant and open-air terrace offers panoramic views of Millennium Park, sparkling Lake Michigan, The Art Institute Of Chicago, and beyond. Join Executive Chef Christian Ragano and his team for seasonally-rotating, family-style comfort food, bio-dynamic wines, and award-winning cocktails with large format apothecaries. With seasonal freshness reflected in food and drink, this Chicago restaurant serves locally-sourced, New American cuisine within the relaxed ambiance of a Great Lakes beach house. Open year-round.'

posts.name: Del Seoul
posts.note: Del Seoul is a no-frills counter-service eatery with Asian fusion eats like Korean BBQ tacos and banh mi sandwiches. You need to order lollipop K-town Chicken Wings or Kalbi (braised short rib) poutine or the Veggie Bibimbop.

posts.name: Do-Rite Donuts & Coffee
posts.note: Do-Rite Donuts and Coffee is a chef-owned stop for artisanal donuts in unusual flavors plus gluten-free and vegan options and coffee. Don't forget to order a spicy chicken sandwich or the bacon, egg, and cheese sandwich for breakfast. Be sure to come early; they may close earlier than 2:00 pm if we run out! NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Doughnut Vault
posts.note: Doughnut Vault is a tiny bakery selling a handful of donut choices each day until the stock runs out. Owner Brendan Sodikoff started selling big, fresh doughnuts out of a brick storefront in the spring of 2011, and lines continue from early morning until the handful of flavors sell out. Outside, there's a communal table for enjoying old-fashioned, chocolate-glazed doughnuts and salted peanuts, with cheap cups of coffee.

posts.name: Dove's Luncheonette
posts.note: Dove's Luncheonette is a Tex-Mex diner eats plus cocktails and lots of tequila in retro digs with counter seats and a jukebox. The burnt ends hash I saw on TV look like the thing to order when you're there.

posts.name: Duck Duck Goat
posts.note: Duck Duck Goat is a creative Chinese fare from celeb chef Stephanie Izard served in buzzy, ornately decorated surrounds.

posts.name: Elske
posts.note: Elske is a low-key spot offering à la carte and tasting menus of creative American fare with Danish influences. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Last December, pedigreed chefs David and Anna Posey (Blackbird, Alinea, Trio) opened their very first restaurant, Elske. Sporting a stylish array of locally sourced, hyper-seasonal ingredients, the spot had one notable lofty ambition: to change the tasting menu game in Chicago by offering a multi-course experience that was simultaneously affordable and laid back. “We were inspired by the modern-style bistros of Paris and throughout Europe — how you could go to Le Chateaubriand and have very forward-thinking food for about $60,” says David. “We just want [customers to get] interesting food that [they] can’t make at home.”'
posts.hrs: Closed Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday

posts.name: Fat Rice
posts.note: Fat Rice serves comfort food from around the world is served in a rustic space with communal tables and an open kitchen. From the Chicago Eater website, 'It’s only fitting, then, that Logan Square’s Fat Rice is considered to be among the crème de la crème of Chicago eateries. The popular Macanese-style restaurant is the crown jewel of the growing “fusion” trend that melds disparate cuisines to produce bold, new flavors. And no dish is more emblematic of the cooking style than Fat Rice’s signature Arroz Gordo.'

posts.name: The Game Room
posts.note: The Game Room in the Chicago Athletic Association Hotel is a retro-chic lounge offering classic cocktails and finger foods, along with bocce, pool, cards, and foosball. From their website, 'Game Room is exactly that — a sprawling space on the second floor of the Chicago Athletic Association packed with shuffleboard, foosball, bocce, billiards, checkers, chess, and more. Accompanying the games is a playful menu of creative takes on street food favorites, including burgers, fried pickle pops, falafel, fried chicken sandwiches, chicken wings, and more. The drink menu includes an accessible selection of classic cocktails, including rotating seasonal variations on Cobblers, Collins, Old Fashioneds, Sours, and more. Game Room also offers a range of craft beers, including limited-edition collaborations with local breweries, and a curated wine list.'

posts.name: Girl and the Goat
posts.note: Girl and the Goat is the hot spot where Stephanie Izard serves up innovative small plates from a dramatic open kitchen. The Girl and the Goat opened with the goal of serving a family-style menu of tasty, bold flavored foods with global influences in a fun and lively setting that makes their guests feel at home from the moment they walk in the door.

posts.name: Honey 1 BBQ
posts.note: Honey 1 BBQ is a family-run rib joint with a fiery secret sauce is a great budget-friendly option in Chicago’s Bucktown neighborhood. Chicagoan Jeff Mauro recommends the Mini Tips Combo: hunks of smoky meat served atop a mountain of fries and bathed in the restaurant's signature sauce. Honey 1 BBQ serves hickory-smoked BBQ classic's and BYOB (Bring your own beer) in a casual, counter-serve storefront with wood tables.

posts.name: Honey Butter Fried Chicken
posts.note: Honey Butter Fried Chicken is a quick-serve outfit furnishes fried poultry, craft beer, and cocktails in rustic digs with a patio. From their website, 'Many years ago, one of the side dishes served during SDC Fried Chicken Dinner was griddled corn cakes with honey butter. Hastily plated portions of the chicken and side were piled high on small plates to be eaten by staff while standing in the kitchen. Somehow, the honey butter melted on the fried chicken. Mind-exploding discovery moment: honey butter is really delicious on fried chicken.' From the Chicago Eater website,'It may not serve your momma’s fried chicken — with bones, skin, et al. — but Honey Butter Fried Chicken makes swaths of Chicagoans feel like kids again when they dip their birds in that addictive honey butter. Since expanding from supper club to Avondale brick-and-mortar in fall 2013, lines form during peak lunch and dinner hours but move quickly at the cozy counter-service space.'

posts.name: Interurban Boathouse
posts.note: Interurban Boathouse is a seasonal selection of pastries plus breakfast and lunch eat's such as oatmeal, sandwiches, and salads. Jason Fried said 'If you’re looking for a great casual, hidden spot for breakfast, lunch, dinner?' he'd recommend Interurban Boathouse.

posts.name: Jim's Original
posts.note: Jim's Original is an old-school 24/7 hot dog stand (started in 1939) boasting the original Maxwell Street Polish sausage. You need to order a pork chop sandwich too.

posts.name: Jimmy's Red Hots
posts.note: Jimmy's Red Hots is a counter-serve stand slinging hot dogs, Polish sausages, fries, and tamales for over 55 years.

posts.name: Johnnie's Beef
posts.note: Johnnie's Beef is a tiny, no-frills, cash-only hot dog stand serving sausage and beef along with Italian ice, fries, and shakes. From the Chicago Tribune 'On the beef sandwich familiarity scale, Italian beef resides beneath the French dip/pastrami/Philly cheesesteak top tier, on the next level down with the Buffalo beef on weck and Baltimore pit beef.'

posts.name: J.P. Graziano Grocery
posts.note: J.P. Graziano Grocery is a long-running Italian market and sandwich shop offering subs and specialty food items since 1937. From their website, 'We are a fourth-generation family-owned and operated Italian grocery store. Located in Chicago’s West Loop, we are the grocery shop with the most established presence and a reputation you can count on. People come for subs, for antipasti trays, for our desserts, and to buy authentic Chicago-style Italian foods for their own pantry. Known locally for our imported Italian delicacies, we’re also a popular choice for lunch for those who are nearby. Some will even come out of their way, craving the taste of our food.'

posts.name: Kuma's Corner
posts.note: Kuma's Corner is a busy, hopping pub known for its long list of creative burgers and its rock 'n' roll soundtrack. I have heard you need to order one of their burgers. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Manny's Coffee Shop and Deli
posts.note: Manny's Coffee Shop and Deli is a storied, no-frills institution serving classic deli fare in a cafeteria-style setting. From their website, 'It is our home away from home. As you walk through our doors, know that we welcome you to our home. Our food and recipes have been handed down from generation to generation.'

posts.name: Mercat a la Planxa
posts.note: Mercat a la Planxa serves a creative Catalan-inspired tapas and inventive cocktails in a swanky setting overlooking Grant Park. My friend recommends the tasing menu and drink pairing. From their website, 'Mercat’s ambitious menu captivates diners with its masterful remix of authentic Spanish cuisine with an emphasis in the Catalonian region. From street food-styled starters to meal-sized classics, rice, and grilled specialties from our planxa grill, each dish leads diners to another stage along Mercat’s culinary adventure. Complementing the rich cultural experience is an extensive, yet finely curated selection of cava, sangria, wine, and cocktail creations.'

posts.name: mfk. restaurant
posts.note: mfk. restaurant is a seafood-focused eatery for rare and global fish dishes in a cozy, seaside-inspired space with a bar.

posts.name: Mr. Beef
posts.note: Mr. Beef is a no-frills spot supplying classic Chicago eats like Italian beef that appeals to late-night diners.You need to order the Italian Beef sandwich and the Chicago Dog with everything.

posts.name: Monteverde Restaurant and Pastificio
posts.note: Monteverde Restaurant and Pastificio is a stylish spot serving refined, contemporary Italian fare such as fresh pasta's, along with global wines. Phil from the show Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) recommends ordering the pork and ricotta ravioli or the Tigelle with prosciutto butter or the pasta with sauce pork Sopressata meatballs, pork sausage, pork shank, and a little salad. From the Chicago Eater website, 'The first restaurant from former Top Chef and Spiaggia chef Sarah Grueneberg has quickly cemented itself as one of Chicago’s top Italian destinations and its tough-to-get reservations are a prime example. The pastas are the stars at the West Loop hotspot, such as cannelloni saltimbocca with merguez lamb sausage, manchego cheese, peas, harissa, and balsamico, many of which are made on a small demonstration stage of sorts behind the bar. Also try non-pasta dishes such as the skate wing schnitzel and ‘nduja arancini, as well as a standout wine list.'

posts.name: Nana
posts.note: Nana is a bright cafe with a seasonal patio cooking up American and Mexican fare for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Order the poached eggs on pupusas with chorizo.

posts.name: Old Town Ale House
posts.note: Old Town Ale House is laid-back, a cash-only dive bar near Second City with a storied past, old-school jukebox and funky art.

posts.name: Old Fashioned Donuts
posts.note: Old Fashioned Donuts is located on a sleepy stretch of Michigan Avenue (yes, THAT Michigan Avenue) since 1972. They have been serving the far South Side neighborhood of Roseland for 41 years. Owner Buritt Bulloch works on display in the front window, a rhythmic concentration on his kindly face and a gloving of flour on his well-worn hands. Regulars queue up in the sunlit foyer, patiently waiting their turn with the owner's daughter behind the counter. Some know exactly what they want, while others are treated to a matter-of-fact recitation of the shop's expansive options. NOTE: Cash only.

posts.name: Pacific Standard Time
posts.note: From the Eater website about Pacific Standard Time, 'Erling Wu-Bower cemented his reputation in Chicago as chef of Nico Osteria, where he excelled at crudos, fish stews, lobster spaghetti, and other Italian seafood jewels. At Pacific Standard Time, his proven repertoire merges with a West Coast ethos, so that coils of chitarra snarl Dungeness crab and a salad starring milky stracciatella comes paired with Harry’s Berries strawberries, some of the finest fruit grown in California. But this is the Golden State of Wu-Bower’s own mind, informed by freethinking multiculturalism rather than an adherence to any one cuisine. So pork and shrimp dumplings can be ordered alongside the pasta, and a handsomely charred mushroom pizza arrives dotted with XO sauce and served with a winky side of ranch dressing. His showstopper is a large-format, two-course duck presentation perfumed with Middle Eastern flavors, including a cast-iron pot domed with pita dough and filled with duck-beef meatballs in a fragrant chickpea stew. Pastry chef Natalie Saben drives home the Midwest-meets-California ideology, with feel-good desserts like the huckleberry sundae and a chocolate tart with peanut dukkah.'
posts.rcmmnd: Eater's 18 Best New Restaurants in America - 2018

posts.name: The Publican
posts.note: The Publican is a creative seafood and pork-focused menu plus global brews in a hip setting with communal tables.

posts.name: Publican Quality Meats
posts.note: Publican Quality Meats is an American cafe offering charcuterie, pastries, and sandwiches along with an on-site butcher and market.

posts.name: Pequod's Pizza
posts.note: Pequod's Pizza is a casual, brick-walled pizza pub where deep-dish pies with caramelized crusts are served until late. Phil from Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) recommends ordering the deep dish pizza, which can be customized. From their website,' The year was 1970. Hidden away on Fernald Avenue in Morton Grove, Illinois, Pequods Pizza started a cult following for its pan-style pizza with a “caramelized crust” edge. Mozzarella cheese is cooked along the edge of a cast-iron pan creating a crust unlike any other. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Rex Italian Foods, Inc
posts.note: Rex Italian Foods, Inc is a counter-serve Italian store that serves entrees, and sandwiches served at a small sit-down section inside a food market. Get their pressed ham, peppers, and cheese sandwich.

posts.name: RPM Steak
posts.note: RPM Steak is a chophouse with a modern menu of prime cuts, raw-bar items and more in a sleek setting with banquettes. I hear you need to order the beef cheeseburger and the lamb burger with middle eastern spices.

posts.name: Saucy Porka
posts.note: Saucy Porka is a modern fusion of Latin and Asian comfort foods from a buzzy spot with food-truck roots. Order their Asian Paella with two types of sausage and glazed pork or pork tacos or the Cubana or pazolli soup which has pork and hominy.

posts.name: The Spice House
posts.note: The Spice House is a bright retail shop for all manner of rubs, salts, and extracts, plus made-in-house spice mixes. Alton Brown recommends ordering your spices from The Spice House, which I did. So no food here but great spice, salts, etc. to make wonderful things. From their website, 'Founded in 1957, The Spice House is a purveyor of the finest spices, herbs, blends, and extracts to customers ranging from renowned Michelin-star chefs to home cooks everywhere. We’ve spent over 60 years curating our global network of premium growers and distributors in order to offer our customers unrivaled quality and selection. Our products range from essential and rare spice varietals to proprietary rubs and blends.'

posts.name: Sun Wah BBQ
posts.note: Sun Wah BBQ is a long-running Chinese eatery known for its Hong Kong-style BBQ dishes, plus beer, and cocktails. It's a family-operated restaurant which has some of the best and most authentic Chinese barbecue in Chicago. Served up Hong Kong-style, menu highlights include peanut butter egg rolls, crispy Beijing duck and a whole roasted suckling pig that Rahm Fama says is 'mouthwateringly delicious.' You need to order the Whole Roasted Suckling Pig, Crispy Duck, the Roast Pork, or the Pork Chow Fun with rice noodles.

posts.name: Sweet Maple Cafe
posts.note: Sweet Maple Cafe is a country-style comfort food including all-day breakfasts, and hearty lunches served in a homey space.

posts.name: Top Notch Beefburgers
posts.note: Top Notch Beefburgers is a South Side spot that has been serving burgers, beef-fat fries, and shakes since 1942.

posts.name: Tortello
posts.note: Tortello serves housemade pasta and sauces from an open kitchen, served at a counter for casual dining or takeout. Jason Fried tweeted, 'Simple menu, seriously good pasta. Very legit. Dario, the owner, is running something special over there.' From their website, 'Born and raised in Italy, Dario Monni has been steeped in the rich food culture of Italy from an early age. In his hometown of Venice, Monni learned the art of preparing handmade pasta from his “nonna” while listening to stories of his grandfather’s specialty foods store. His summers were spent with relatives on his father’s side in rural Sardinia, where his family worked as shepherds, cheese-mongers, and butchers, imparting onto him the deep-rooted value of the region’s unique rituals, pristine ingredients and simple dedication to an authentic craft.

posts.name: Tortillería y Taquerías Atotonilco
posts.note: Tortillería y Taquerías Atotonilco is a local Mexican counter-serve chain offering breakfast, tacos, burritos and shakes in a low-key space. My buddy says the thing to order is the El Pastor and the skirt steak tacos with corn tortillas which were fantastic. NOTE: They have multiple locations with the original one located at 3916 W. 26th St., Chicago, IL 60623, and its phone number is 773-762-3380.

posts.name: urbanbelly
posts.note: The functional eatery urbanbelly is whipping up hearty Asian fusion grub in straightforward digs with communal tables. I heard the thing to order there are their dumplings. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Valois Restaurant
posts.note: Valois Restaurant is a counter-service smorgasbord of American comfort food served in a casual, muraled space. NOTE: Cash only.

posts.name: Virtue Restaurant
posts.note: Virtue Restaurant serves hearty Southern cooking paired with wines and cocktails in funky-chic quarters with an open kitchen. Phil from Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) recommends the Salmon and succotash with corn puree. From their website, 'Stationed in the Hyde Park neighborhood of Chicago, Virtue is a Southern American restaurant that leads with a culture of hospitality and kindness. We’ve worked hard to create a warm, honest, and thoughtful space. We pride ourselves on unpretentious service, timing, and, most importantly, providing great value. At Virtue, we use heritage techniques to create some familiar flavors and some new ones. We hope to see you soon.'
